title: 111_s1520
content: CHAPTER 1504 - NATIONAL AMERICAN INDIAN VETERANS, INCORPORATED: This section recognizes the corporation and grants a federal charter to National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated under Part B of subtitle II of title 36, United States Code. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is a federally chartered nonprofit corporation in the United States with specific purposes outlined in its organization. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is a federally chartered corporation in the United States with purposes including upholding the Constitution and uniting American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is a federally chartered corporation in the United States that advocates for American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans, promoting social welfare and serving as an advocate for their needs. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated advocates for American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans, promoting social welfare, serving as an advocate for their needs, supporting research on their relationship with American society, and providing technical assistance to regions without veterans committees or organizations. Sec. 150403. Membership eligibility and rights in the corporation shall be as provided in the constitution and by-laws. Sec. 150404. Board of directors. Membership in the corporation, rights, and privileges are outlined in the constitution and by-laws. The board of directors' responsibilities are defined in accordance with the laws of incorporation. Officers and their election process are also governed by the constitution and by-laws. The corporation's membership, board of directors' responsibilities, and officers' election process are outlined in the constitution and bylaws. The corporation is prohibited from discriminating based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin, handicap, or age. The corporation's powers are limited to those granted in its articles of incorporation and constitution. The corporation's powers are limited to those granted in its articles of incorporation and constitution. The corporation has the exclusive right to use specific names, seals, emblems, and badges. Sec. 150409. Restrictions: The corporation is prohibited from issuing stock, declaring dividends, or distributing income or assets to members, officers, or directors during the charter's lifespan. The corporation is prohibited from issuing stock, declaring dividends, or distributing income or assets to members, officers, or directors during the charter's lifespan. Additionally, the corporation shall not make any loans to its officers, directors, members, or employees. It is also not allowed to claim congressional approval or Federal Government authority for its activities. The corporation must maintain its tax-exempt status as an organization. The corporation must maintain its tax-exempt status as an organization by keeping correct and complete books and records of accounts, minutes of proceedings, and a record of members with voting rights. The corporation must maintain accurate records of members with voting rights at its principal office. All books and records can be inspected by members or their representatives for any proper purpose at any reasonable time, without contravening applicable laws. The corporation must comply with the laws of jurisdictions where it operates. It is liable for the acts of its officers and agents within their authority. The corporation is liable for the acts of its officers and agents within their authority. Failure to comply with chapter restrictions will result in charter expiration. The corporation must submit an annual report to Congress on its activities. The corporation must submit an annual report to Congress on its activities, which should be submitted along with the audit report. The annual report is not intended for public distribution. "1504. National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated..... 150401"
